stem: A 52-year-old client with a urinary tract infection (UTI) is increasingly confused and hypotensive. Based on the provided information, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two appropriate nursing actions, and two essential parameters to monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Suspected sepsis progression.
Background: Admitted for pyelonephritis; history of type 2 diabetes.
Assessment: Skin is flushed, dry, and warm. Client is restless and disoriented.
Recommendation: Obtain immediate lactate level and blood cultures.

tabs.title: Sepsis & Perfusion Log
tabs.content:
AssessmentCurrent FindingInterpretation
Cardiac OutputIncreased (Hyperdynamic)Systemic vasodilation
Lactate Level4.8 mmol/L (High)Inadequate tissue perfusion
Urine Output18 mL in last 2 hoursOliguria
Skin StatusWarm; Flushed; PinkEarly phase sign

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 88/42 mmHg, HR 122 bpm, RR 26 breaths/min, T 103.2°F (39.6°C), SpO2 94% on room air.

actionOptions.text: Obtain blood cultures (aerobic and anaerobic) from two sites
Administer a rapid IV bolus of 30 mL/kg crystalloid solution
Apply cooling measures to address the elevated temperature
Elevate the head of the bed to improve breathing

parameterOptions.text: Serum Lactate and Central Venous Oxygen Saturation (ScvO2)

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting signs of early (warm) septic shock (c1), characterized by warm, flushed skin, fever, hypotension, and a hyperdynamic state. The elevated lactate level (4.8 mmol/L) confirms inadequate tissue perfusion. Priority nursing actions include obtaining blood cultures before administering antibiotics (a1) and initiating aggressive fluid resuscitation with a 30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus (a2) to address vasodilation. Monitoring Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) (p1) and serum lactate levels (p2) are crucial for assessing the effectiveness of interventions and guiding further treatment.
clinicalPearls: Lactate levels > 2.0 mmol/L indicate sepsis; levels > 4.0 mmol/L suggest septic shock.
In early sepsis, vasodilation causes warm skin; in late sepsis, vasoconstriction leads to cold, mottled skin.
The 30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus is a standard initial treatment for septic shock.

questionTrap.trap: Applying cooling measures to address the warm, flushed skin.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: The flushing in sepsis is due to vasodilation, not solely the fever. Cooling measures alone will not resolve the underlying hypotension. Prioritize fluid resuscitation and addressing the infection.

mnemonic.title: Sepsis Management
mnemonic.expansion: Remember the acronym 'BLAST': Blood cultures, Lactate, Antibiotics, Stat fluids, Track MAP.
